Comments_List: Learning the economic history of Latin America and understanding the reasons for its underdevelopment.
rigorous examination of development economics with a historical and current affairs context.

Overview of Latin American economic history from colonial era to the present
Ability to skim/synthesize historical economic papers

There are very very long readings assigned for each week, and even though I couldn't do all of them each time, I definitely have a very good sense of the general academic discourse around economic development especially in Latin America. The course is presentation-based, and Professor Zedillo's insights were very helpful in guiding us through the theories.
I learned the complexity of Latin America's mediocre economic development

Strength: Very interesting readings, class is engaging 
Weakness: probably it would be better if we could receive more feedback on our reading response.

Strengths: hearing about about Prof. Zedillo's personal experiences is incredible
Weaknesses: absolutely no feedback throughout the whole semester, plus classes are just student-run presentations

I wish Professor Zedillo lectured more on specific topics and gave more background. I was a lot more interested in what he had to say than in the students' presentations, which took up most of the time. It would be great if the presentations were 40 min long, and the rest of the time was split between lecture and discussion. The TA wasn't helpful at all. His role in the class was unclear, and he did not give useful feedback on the weekly reading responses that I spent hours reading for and writing (with very little idea of what they were supposed to look like.)
Maybe a final comment that sums up the main points of each class

Professor Zedillo is of course fascinating and I learned a lot from him. The material is also pretty interesting, especially if you're interested in macroeconomic policy. However, I didn't love the presentations format. I found that because presentations lasted the whole class, there was rarely any meaningful discussion between students. Mostly students would just direct questions to Professor Zedillo.
Yes. If you interested in development economics.
If you're interested in the subject, definitely!
Great course and really incredible experience to be in a class with Zedillo
Absolutely take it if you're interested in development econ/central banking etc.! Or if you're an econ or ep&e major, Prof Zedillo is amazing. It's worth the Friday 9am hike to Watson Center.
It all depends on the student, you can't make a general recommendation of a class with such a specific topic
